content: Hi, I'm wondering what people think of this idea: start a WG-comments whose only task is to write doc comments for the compiler. The idea is that thorough doc comments would make it way easier to jump into the compiler as a beginner, whereas currently a lot of the compiler is undocumented and mysterious, and many contributors report feeling overwhelmed/not knowing where to start.
Writing comments is a task that can be done incrementally with little chunks of time and doesn't require any setup to build the compiler.
And at the same time, learning something well enough to write comments may be a good intro for someone to contribute further.
Thoughts?
I've thought about trying to write some docs, but I'm pretty new and so don't feel confident enough in my knowledge of how things work

I think it would be a good intro to better understanding, but I think there's a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem since you need to understand stuff to write docs, but you need docs to understand stuff.
The thing is
That more than a chicken and egg problem, we have a lot of "oral tradition", if you wish
Lots of the relevant knowledge about the compiler is in the people that work and have worked on it
And it's transmitted by asking questions and stuff
But I think that you're right, @Camelid, in the sense that one needs to understand how things work in order to write about how they work :3
@mark-i-m this is so my jam. I wanna write doc comments all day long
If this WG gets made, please do add me
This is a bit of a pet peeve that I have with the current documentation
I mean don't get me wrong; whatever is there has helped me a lot. But there's so much, so so much missing.
At least around the miri and mir-opt parts. I haven't worked much with the rest of the compiler yet x3
I think this is a great idea - I'd be more than happy to help if you got this going
Having some guidance on how to go about writing doc comments (and improving the workflow around it) would be helpful
good idea... rustc comments don't get lots of love, and since this is internal stuff, I think perhaps all of them should be exposed to rustdoc
also, s/comments/rustc-comments
Cool, so this is helpful feedback.

Here is how I've done this in the past when approaching a large unknown piece of code: I try to find what looks like the entry point of some code that I know the high-level purpose of (i.e. "I know this code parses macros somehow"). Then, I just start reading that code and leaving (normal) comments for myself as I read. Eventually, I get a good enough picture of what
...'s going on to write reasonable doc comments
I think if we do such a WG, though, we should liberally take advantage of the compiler team to find out what the high-level design of something is, and then we can figure out the details
Oh, wow, I just noticed that there is a submodules = false config in config.toml
sorry, wrong topic
I'm in favor of the plan
